text_clipping.text: creativity is the ability to produce work that is both novel (i.e. original, unexpected) and appropriate (i.e. useful, adaptive concerning task constraints).

google_book.title: Handbook of creativity
google_book.description: The Handbook of Creativity provides a comprehensive, definitive, and authoritative single-volume review of t he entire field of creativity. Twenty-two chapters introduce the field and deal with methods in studying creativity, origins of creativity, the self and environment in creativity, special topics in creativity, and conclusions. Each of the essays are written to be accessible to all educated readers.
google_book.about_the_authors: Robert J. Sternberg is Dean of Arts and Sciences at Tufts University. Prior to that, he was IBM Professor of Psychology and Education in the Department of Psychology, Professor of Management in the School of Management, and Director of the Center for the Psychology of Abilities, Competencies, and Expertise (PACE) at Yale. He continues to direct the Center from Tufts. He is the author of more than 1000 journal articles, book chapters, and books, and has received over $18 million in government and other grants and contracts for his research.

text_clipping.text: at a societal level, creativity can lead to new scientific findings, new movements in art, new inventions, and new social programs
with regard to the confluence of components, creativity is hypothesized to involve more than a simple sum of a person's attained level of functioning on each component.
new thoughts generally arise with a play of the mind, and the failure to appreciate this is actually one of the major blocks to creativity.

google_book.title: Science, order, and creativity
google_book.description: How can science, when it is based on a narrow perspective of life, ever understand the essence of natural problems since they occur in a much wider context? InScience, Order & Creativity,David Bohm and F. David Peat present a compelling argument that science, in fact, cannot hope to provide answers when its approach is narrow and fragmented from other disciplines such as philosophy, art, and religion. A revolutionary approach to scientific inquiry,Science, Order & Creativityis an accessible entry into the extraordinary work of one of the century's greatest thinkers, David Bohm.
google_book.about_the_authors: Bohm was Emeritus Professor of Theoretical Physics, University of London.

publication.title: Revolutions Theories and Creativity in Science
The Generative Order and the Implicate Order
Generative Order in Science Society and
Creativity in the Whole of Life

text_clipping.text: 'creativity' is eventually, provisionally, defined as re...creation

google_book.title: Creativity:theory, history, practice
google_book.description: Creativity: Theory, History, Practice offers important new perspectives on creativity in the light of contemporary critical theory and cultural history. Innovative in approach as well as argument, the book crosses disciplinary boundaries and builds new bridges between the critical and the creative. It is organized in four parts:Â· Why creativity now? offers much-needed alternatives to both the Romantic stereotype of the creator as individual genius and the tendency of the modern creative industries to treat everything as a commodity.Â· Defining creativity, creating definitions traces the changing meaning of "create" from religious ideas of divine creation from nothing to advertising notions of concept creation. It also examines the complex history and extraordinary versatility of terms such as imagination, invention, inspiration and originality.Â· Creation as myth, story, metaphor begins with modern re-telling of early African, American and Australian creation myths and -picking up Biblical and evolutionary accounts along the way - works round to scientific visions of the Big Bang, bubble universes and cosmic soup.Â· Creative practices, cultural processes is a critical anthology of materials, chosen to promote fresh thinking about everything from changing constructions of "literature" and "design" to artificial intelligence and genetic engineering.Rob Pope takes significant steps forward in the process of rethinking a vexed yet vital concept, all the while encouraging and equipping readers to continue the process in their own creative or "re-creative" ways. Creativity: Theory, History, Practice is invaluable for anyone with a live interest in exploring what creativity has been, is currently, and yet may be.

publication.title: Part 3 Creation as myth story metaphor

text_clipping.text: ways of expressing the dynamic between 'free play' and 'bound game': the relation between creativity and constraint. for it is precisely through game-like constraints - as long as there are not too many and too inhibiting - that playful creativity is stimulated to emerge.
